metadata.case_name: Nagpur Electric Light & Power Co. Ltd. & Ors. v. Regional Director, Employees' State Insurance Corporation & Ors.

facts.text: Nagpur Electric Light & Power Co. Ltd. occupies premises at Kamptee Road, Nagpur, within a compound wall, carrying on work of transforming and transmitting electrical energy received in bulk at 11,000 volts from Maharashtra State Electricity Board's generating station at Khaparkheda.
Premises include receiving station, workshop, meter testing department, engineers' quarters, general office, and stores in different buildings inside the premises.
Company does not generate electricity; receives energy at receiving station, steps it down to 3,300 volts or directly to 400 volts at sub-stations, then distributes to consumers.
Company and employees filed applications before Employees Insurance Court under s.75 ESI Act claiming workers in appendices 1-2 are employees under s.2(9), but those in 3-5 are not.
Regional Director contested applications but admitted workers in items 5-14 of appendix 4 and items 1,7,8 of appendix 5 are not employees under s.2(9).
Employees Insurance Court found those workers and item 12 of appendix 5 are not employees; correctness not in issue.
Employees Insurance Court held workers in appendix III, items 1-4 appendix IV, items 2-6 and 9-11 appendix V are employees under s.2(9).
Company and employees appealed to Bombay High Court Nagpur Bench under s.82; Abhayankar J. affirmed and dismissed; Letters Patent Appeals summarily dismissed on September 17, 1963.

Disputed categories: Appendix III (Mains Senior: assistant engineers, supervisors, electricians, overseers; Mains junior: cable jointers, mistries etc.; Clerical staff; Stores; Motor car staff; Mason).
Appendix IV items 1-4: Meter senior/junior (deputy meter superintendent, senior/junior meter mechanic, meter testers).
Appendix V items 2-6,9-11: Accounts dept clerks, time-keeping clerks, filing clerks, typing dept, telephone operators, record-keeper, station clerk, motor car staff, menial staff.
More than 20 persons working on premises on any day of preceding 12 months.
All disputed workers employed on remuneration not exceeding Rs.400/month.

legal_issues.text: Whether the premises occupied by the company constitute a factory within the meaning of s.2(12) of the Employees' State Insurance Act, 1948.
Whether the members of staff in disputed categories (appendices III, IV items 1-4, V items 2-6,9-11) are employees within the meaning of s.2(9) of the ESI Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Workers in appendices 3,4,5 (disputed categories) are not employees under s.2(9).

respondent_arguments.text: Disputed workers are employees under s.2(9); admitted some specific categories are not.

court_reasoning.text: Premises constitute a factory under s.2(12) as 20+ persons working, and manufacturing process (transforming/transmitting electrical energy under s.2(k) Factories Act) carried on with aid of power in part thereof; entire premises including precincts is factory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Transforming electrical energy from high to low potential and transmitting through supply lines are manufacturing processes.

court_reasoning.text: Factory has fixed site bounded by compound wall; not extending to entire transmission area including sub-stations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rejects High Court's view that entire transmission area is factory.

court_reasoning.text: All disputed workers employed for wages in or in connection with work of factory, directly by principal employer on work of/incidental/preliminary/connected with factory work.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Definition in s.2(9) wider than 'worker' in Factories Act; extends to those working elsewhere if connected with factory work.

court_reasoning.text: Details duties: engineers/supervisors etc. for erection/maintenance of lines; clerks/storekeepers for support; meter staff for testing; admin clerks for accounts/records connected to factory operations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Clerical/non-manual workers can be employees if in connection with factory work; no separate unconnected establishment.

court_reasoning.text: Sub-stations not independent factories; attendants' work connected to main factory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: ESI Corp v. Raman distinguished as there was separate sales office unconnected to factory work.

holdings.text: Premises constitute a factory under s.2(12) ESI Act.
Disputed category workers are employees under s.2(9)(i) ESI Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ardeshir Bhiwaniwala v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Premises constituting factory may be building or open land; inside same compound wall, some premises may/may not be factory.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. M.P. Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Factories Act benefits do not extend to field workers outside factory.

precedents_cited.case_name: Employees' State Insurance Corporation, Bombay v. Raman
precedents_cited.relevance: Clerks in separate administrative office handling sales not employees under s.2(9); unlike here where all connected to factory work.

statutes_cited.name: Employees' State Insurance Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Applies to factories; defines factory, employee; jurisdiction of Insurance Court and appeals.

statutes_cited.name: Factories Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines power and manufacturing process (includes transforming/transmitting power); contrasts worker definition.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed; confirmed that premises is factory and disputed workers are employees under s.2(9) ESI Act.

key_quotes.text: "In view of s.2(k)(iii), the process of transforming electrical energy from a high to a low potential and the process of transmitting the energy through supply lines are both manufacturing processes."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines transforming/transmitting as manufacturing process, key to factory status.

key_quotes.text: "The definition of employee in s.2(9) is wider than that of a worker in s.2(l) of the Factories Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains broader coverage under ESI Act.

key_quotes.text: "A factory must occupy a fixed site... The company's factory has a fixed site. It is located inside the Kamptee Road and its boundaries are fixed by the compound wall."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits factory to premises, rejects expansive High Court view.
